Section.HTML:
Cervical cysts — mucus-filled lumps that form on the cervix — are rarely cancerous. These cysts form when normal tissue on the outer part of the cervix (squamous epithelium) grows over the glandular, mucus-producing tissue of the inner part of the cervix (endocervical canal), trapping mucus and forming cysts.

Cervical cysts often are discovered incidentally during a pelvic exam. They generally don't cause symptoms and require no treatment.

If a cervical cyst looks unusual to your doctor, or you also have signs and symptoms that suggest cervical cancer — for instance, abnormal vaginal bleeding or discharge, pelvic pain, or pain during intercourse — your doctor may perform a biopsy of your cervix.

Thumbnail.Alt: Medical illustration of a cervical cyst
Thumbnail.Caption: A cervical cyst appears as a fluid-filled lump on the cervix — the neck-shaped end of the uterus that extends into the vagina. Cervical cysts are usually harmless and often resolve on their own.
Thumbnail.Title: Cervical cyst

Image.Caption: A cervical cyst appears as a fluid-filled lump on the cervix — the neck-shaped end of the uterus that extends into the vagina. Cervical cysts are usually harmless and often resolve on their own.

Answer.Title: Cervical cysts: Can they be cancerous?
Answer.Abstract: Most cervical cysts cause no signs or symptoms and require no treatment.
Answer.Question: Can cervical cysts be cancerous?
